name: IPv6
description: Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) is the successor to IPv4, providing a vastly larger address space (128-bit addresses) and improved features like simplified headers, built-in IPSec, and stateless autoconfiguration.
key_topics: IPv6 address format and notation (hexadecimal, double colon compression)
IPv6 address types: Unicast (Global, Link-local, Unique local), Multicast, Anycast
ICMPv6 and its role in IPv6
Dual-stack, tunneling, and translation transition mechanisms
common_misconceptions: Training materials often state IPv6 eliminates broadcasts. Cisco documentation clarifies IPv6 uses multicast instead, with specific addresses like FF02::1 (all nodes) and FF02::2 (all routers)
Many resources claim SLAAC makes DHCP unnecessary. Cisco config guides explain DHCPv6 is still needed for DNS server info and other options not provided by SLAAC

Third-party books frequently confuse link-local (FE80::/10) with unique local (FC00::/7) addresses. Link-local are non-routable and mandatory on all IPv6 interfaces; unique local are routable within an organization
Common error: forgetting ipv6 unicast-routing command. Without this global command, the router will not forward IPv6 packets or advertise itself as a router via NDP
